               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear" style="height:20px;">

                <p>

              <h2 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-bottom-border wpex-block wpex-border-b wpex-border-solid wpex-border-main">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Erasmus Mundus Master Chemical NanoEngineering
               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear">
              </div>
              <div class="wpb_text_column has-custom-color wpex-child-inherit-color wpb_content_element wpex-antialiased" style="color:rgba(30,21,23,0.9);font-size:18px;">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 The
                 <strong>
                  CNE program
                 </strong>
                 is a joint master program in Chemical Nanoengineering offered by three European universities:
                </p>
                <ul>
                 <li>
                  Aix-Marseille University (France)
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Tor Vergata University of Rome (Italy)
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Wroclaw University of science and Technology (Poland)
                 </li>
                </ul>
                <p>
                 Chemistry for Nanoengineering is an innovative field of science and technology which is developing very fast. The 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry shows the importance of the research in this area. It has shown that engineering of the Nanomachines is not any more a science-fiction; it is just a beginning of new engineering specialty where the Nano-systems can be numerically designed and chemically synthesized. These new technologies will create a large demand for specialists in this field.
                </p>
               </div>

              <h2 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-plain wpex-block wpex-text-center aligncenter vcex_67ef16470d434" style="color:#222222;font-weight:700;line-height:120%;width:700px;">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Do you want to be a sponsor?
               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear" style="height:30px;">
              </div>
              <div class="wpb_text_column wpex-max-w-100 wpex-mx-auto wpb_content_element" style="width:1000px;">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 We welcome contact from your organisation and are happy to discuss any idea which could facilitate the recruitment of CNE students
                 <br/>
                 <strong>
                  There are three main ways
                 </strong>
                 to sponsor and/or become a business partner of the CNE programme.
                </p>
                <ol>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Student Sponsorship program
                  </strong>
                  : Your organization will have the possibility of sponsoring a qualified CNE student selected jointly by your organization and CNE admission and evaluation committee. Full-funding scholarship is named and advertised under your organization name. The relationship between your organization and the student may be defined in the grant admission criteria.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Internship program
                  </strong>
                  : CNE students perform their master thesis placement during the second year (February-June period). You can participate in this program by offering our students an opportunity to perform the internship in your organization. You will have the opportunity to select the candidate.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Supporting the CNE programme
                  </strong>
                  : You can also directly sponsor the CNE program and participate in the Advisory Board
                 </li>
                </ol>
               </div>
              </div>

              <h2 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-plain wpex-block wpex-text-center aligncenter vcex_67ef1647752c9" style="color:#222222;font-weight:700;line-height:120%;width:700px;">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Do you want to be a sponsor?
               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear" style="height:30px;">
              </div>
              <div class="wpb_text_column wpex-max-w-100 wpex-mx-auto wpb_content_element" style="width:1000px;">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 We welcome contact from your organisation and are happy to discuss any idea which could facilitate the recruitment of CNE students
                 <br/>
                 <strong>
                  There are three main ways
                 </strong>
                 to sponsor and/or become a business partner of the CNE programme.
                </p>
                <ol>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Student Sponsorship program
                  </strong>
                  : Your organization will have the possibility of sponsoring a qualified CNE student selected jointly by your organization and CNE admission and evaluation committee. Full-funding scholarship is named and advertised under your organization name. The relationship between your organization and the student may be defined in the grant admission criteria.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Internship program
                  </strong>
                  : CNE students perform their master thesis placement during the second year (February-June period). You can participate in this program by offering our students an opportunity to perform the internship in your organization. You will have the opportunity to select the candidate.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Supporting the CNE programme
                  </strong>
                  : You can also directly sponsor the CNE program and participate in the Advisory Board
                 </li>
                </ol>
               </div>

						var nl = new Array(e.rl.length),
							ix = 0,
							sl;
						e.tabw = e.tabhide>=pw ? 0 : e.tabw;
						e.thumbw = e.thumbhide>=pw ? 0 : e.thumbw;
						e.tabh = e.tabhide>=pw ? 0 : e.tabh;

						var m = pw>(e.gw[ix]+e.tabw+e.thumbw) ? 1 : (pw-(e.tabw+e.thumbw)) / (e.gw[ix]);

               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Do you want to be a sponsor?
               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear" style="height:30px;">
              </div>
              <div class="wpb_text_column wpex-max-w-100 wpex-mx-auto wpb_content_element" style="width:1000px;">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 We welcome contact from your organisation and are happy to discuss any idea which could facilitate the recruitment of CNE students
                 <br/>
                 <strong>
                  There are three main ways
                 </strong>
                 to sponsor and/or become a business partner of the CNE programme.
                </p>
                <ol>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Student Sponsorship program
                  </strong>
                  : Your organization will have the possibility of sponsoring a qualified CNE student selected jointly by your organization and CNE admission and evaluation committee. Full-funding scholarship is named and advertised under your organization name. The relationship between your organization and the student may be defined in the grant admission criteria.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Internship program
                  </strong>
                  : CNE students perform their master thesis placement during the second year (February-June period). You can participate in this program by offering our students an opportunity to perform the internship in your organization. You will have the opportunity to select the candidate.
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <strong>
                   Supporting the CNE programme
                  </strong>
                  : You can also directly sponsor the CNE program and participate in the Advisory Board
                 </li>
                </ol>
               </div>

     <div class="container wpex-clr" id="content-wrap">
      <div class="content-area wpex-clr" id="primary">
       <div class="site-content wpex-clr" id="content">
        <article class="single-page-article wpex-clr" id="single-blocks">
         <div class="single-page-content single-content entry wpex-clr">
          <div class="vc_row wpb_row vc_row-fluid">
           <div class="wpb_column vc_column_container vc_col-sm-12">
            <div class="vc_column-inner">
             <div class="wpb_wrapper">
              <div class="wpb_text_column wpb_content_element">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 This Master Course offers an original
                 <strong>
                  program in the highly innovative domain
                 </strong>
                 of nano-engineering. Skills will be acquired at the strongly
                 <strong>
                  interdisciplinary level
                 </strong>
                 needed to master emerging nano-technologies and to develop original concepts and applications aiming at
                 <strong>
                  novel engineering breakthroughs
                 </strong>
                 in many domains;
                 <strong>
                  biomedical
                 </strong>
                 nanotechnologies,
                 <strong>
                  nanomaterials
                 </strong>
                 or applications for
                 <strong>
                  environment
                 </strong>
                 .
                </p>
                <p>
                 The originality of our program is that it deepens the principles of chemistry and engineering with a special orientation in the field of nanotechnology and a strong address to the
                 <strong>
                  industrial reality
                 </strong>
                 . Another originality of our program is based on the extensively developed courses dealing with
                 <strong>
                  the numerical design and engineering
                 </strong>
                 <strong>
                  applications
                 </strong>
                 of nano-systems. Our program is aimed at methodologies applied to nano-engineering, application-oriented and specifically focused on
                 <strong>
                  chemical synthesis and characterization
                 </strong>
                 . It aims at the methodology of bottom-up designing of nano-systems using
                 <strong>
                  modeling and chemical synthesis at the nano-scale
                 </strong>
                 .
                </p>
                <p>
                 Chemistry for nano-engineering is an innovative field of science and technology which is developing very fast. The 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry shows the importance of the research in this area. It has shown that
                 <strong>
                  engineering of the nano-machines is not any more a science-fiction
                 </strong>
                 ; it is just a beginning of new engineering specialty where the nano-systems can be numerically designed and chemically synthesized. These new technologies will create a large demand for specialists in this field.
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="vc_row wpb_row vc_row-fluid">
           <div class="wpb_column vc_column_container vc_col-sm-12">
            <div class="vc_column-inner">
             <div class="wpb_wrapper">
              <h3 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-bottom-border wpex-block vc_custom_1657012476639 wpex-border-b wpex-border-solid wpex-border-main" style="font-size:var(--wpex-text-2xl);">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Competences
               </span>
              </h3>
              <div class="vcex-module vcex-bullets vcex-bullets-check">
               <ul>
                <li>
                 Thorough knowledge of the principles of nano-chemistry and nano-engineering
                </li>
                <li>
                 Thorough knowledge of modelling and numerical simulation methods at multi-scale
                </li>
                <li>
                 Ability to synthesize nano-objects by chemical ways, to characterise and model them, and apply nano-objects particularly in nano-machines, supramolecular assemblies and in medical nano-devices
                </li>
                <li>
                 Capacity to manage and to use nanotechnologies to create new devices
                </li>
                <li>
                 Capacity to promote and to develop scientific and technological innovation
                </li>
                <li>
                 Possibility of making a critical analysis of scientific information
                </li>
                <li>
                 Capacity of technical and economic evaluation of a project of innovation and research
                </li>
                <li>
                 Aptitude to occupy leading positions in science and engineering
                </li>
                <li>
                 Ability to integrate in a professional organisation and develop ethics and responsibility
                </li>
                <li>
                 Capacity to work effectively in a team project
                </li>
               </ul>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="vc_row wpb_row vc_row-fluid">
           <div class="wpb_column vc_column_container vc_col-sm-12">
            <div class="vc_column-inner">
             <div class="wpb_wrapper">
              <h3 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-bottom-border wpex-block vc_custom_1657012470277 wpex-border-b wpex-border-solid wpex-border-main" style="font-size:var(--wpex-text-2xl);">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr">
                Master Objectives
               </span>
              </h3>
              <div class="vcex-module vcex-bullets vcex-bullets-check">
               <ul>
                <li>
                 Assure an interdisciplinary training in the field of nano-engineering, which includes a profound understanding of the chemistry and the methods of synthesis and characterization of nano-materials and nano-systems
                </li>
                <li>
                 Give the students expertise in numerical modeling to predict the chemical and physical properties at the nano-scale
                </li>
                <li>
                 Train the students to synthesize, characterise and model objects of the nano-world, in order to understand their properties, using disciplinary knowledge of fundamental sciences and transdisciplinary knowledge of nano-sciences
                </li>
                <li>
                 Develop a creative experimental approach to prepare, characterise and model nano-objects (nanostructures, nanomaterials or nano-devices) with unknown properties, or resolve problems related to their identification/application/production
                </li>
                <li>
                 Prepare the students for a career in the field of nanotechnology, by offering them a robust experience in this multidisciplinary domain of sciences and engineering
                </li>
                <li>
                 Prepare the students to construct and realize individually or in a team all steps of a research and development project in the domain of nano-sciences et nanotechnologies, mobilising various pluridisciplinary parties
                </li>
                <li>
                 Enable the students to conceive, prepare and use nano-objects in various professional contexts, integrating ethical environmental and societal challenges
                </li>
                <li>
                 Train highly qualified and creative graduates for the labour market with a big capacity to adapt themselves and to find new solutions for technological development (problem solving)
                </li>
                <li>
                 Educate a new generation of engineers who can participate in the creation of new high-technology companies
                </li>
               </ul>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>

                    Fourth semester: Master thesis (30 ECTS)
                   </td>
                  </tr>
                 </tbody>
                </table>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="vcex-spacing wpex-w-100 wpex-clear" style="height:40px;">
              </div>
              <div class="wpb_text_column wpb_content_element">
               <div class="wpb_wrapper">
                <p>
                 <strong>
                  All courses are taught in English, so proficiency in English is required.
                 </strong>
                 Two of the Partners are engineering Universities (PL and IT), which is important for the program goals towards excellence in nano-engineering innovation. The third partner (FR) has a strong chemical nano-science profile which will allows us to teach our students the chemical fundamentals during the first semester in Marseille. The complementarity among the three partners plays a key role in coherence of the joint program: (you find the description of courses here constantly being updated).
                </p>
                <p>
                 The
                 <strong>
                  first year
                 </strong>
                 of studies (Marseille : September – January ; Wroclaw : February – June) is common for all students. The First semester of the
                 <strong>
                  second year
                 </strong>
                 (Rome : October – January) allows the students to choose between two options: experimantal one and numerical one.
                </p>
                <p>
                 The
                 <strong>
                  Master thesis
                 </strong>
                 research project (30 ects, Marseille, Wroclaw, Rome or one of the Partner Institution ; February – August) is intended to bring the student in close contact with a multinational and multidisciplinary research environment of a research institute in academia or in industry. The student can choose among the list of proposed relevant research project and work in close collaboration with other researchers. The research project is finalized with a public presentation of a Master’s Thesis in Marseille in September. The Master Thesis project is evaluated by an external international jury.
                </p>
               </div>

					e.mh = e.mh===undefined || e.mh=="" || e.mh==="auto" ? 0 : parseInt(e.mh,0);
					if(e.layout==="fullscreen" || e.l==="fullscreen")
						newh = Math.max(e.mh,window.RSIH);
					else{
						e.gw = Array.isArray(e.gw) ? e.gw : [e.gw];
						for (var i in e.rl) if (e.gw[i]===undefined || e.gw[i]===0) e.gw[i] = e.gw[i-1];
						e.gh = e.el===undefined || e.el==="" || (Array.isArray(e.el) && e.el.length==0)? e.gh : e.el;
						e.gh = Array.isArray(e.gh) ? e.gh : [e.gh];
						for (var i in e.rl) if (e.gh[i]===undefined || e.gh[i]===0) e.gh[i] = e.gh[i-1];
											
						var nl = new Array(e.rl.length),
							ix = 0,
							sl;
						e.tabw = e.tabhide>=pw ? 0 : e.tabw;
						e.thumbw = e.thumbhide>=pw ? 0 : e.thumbw;
						e.tabh = e.tabhide>=pw ? 0 : e.tabh;
						e.thumbh = e.thumbhide>=pw ? 0 : e.thumbh;
						for (var i in e.rl) nl[i] = e.rl[i]<window.RSIW ? 0 : e.rl[i];
						sl = nl[0];
						for (var i in nl) if (sl>nl[i] && nl[i]>0) { sl = nl[i]; ix=i;}
						var m = pw>(e.gw[ix]+e.tabw+e.thumbw) ? 1 : (pw-(e.tabw+e.thumbw)) / (e.gw[ix]);
						newh =  (e.gh[ix] * m) + (e.tabh + e.thumbh);
					}
					var el = document.getElementById(e.c);
					if (el!==null && el) el.style.height = newh+"px";
					el = document.getElementById(e.c+"_wrapper");
					if (el!==null && el) {
						el.style.height = newh+"px";
						el.style.display = "block";

             <div class="wpb_wrapper">
              <h2 class="vcex-heading vcex-module wpex-text-2xl wpex-font-normal wpex-m-auto wpex-max-w-100 vcex-heading-bottom-border-w-color wpex-block vc_custom_1656929617823 wpex-border-b-2 wpex-border-solid wpex-border-main" style="font-size:var(--wpex-text-2xl);">
               <span class="vcex-heading-inner wpex-inline-block wpex-clr wpex-relative wpex-pb-5 wpex-border-b-2 wpex-border-solid wpex-border-accent">
                1st semester (AMU, Marseille) courses syllabus
               </span>
              </h2>
              <div class="vcex-toggle-group vcex-module wpex-mx-auto vcex-toggle-group--w-borders">
               <div class="vcex-module vcex-toggle" data-animate="true" data-duration="300">
                <div class="vcex-toggle__heading">
                 <a aria-controls="vcex_67ef1648b08fd" aria-expanded="false" class="vcex-toggle__trigger wpex-flex wpex-items-center wpex-transition-colors wpex-duration-200" href="#vcex_67ef1648b08fd">
                  <div aria-hidden="true" class="vcex-toggle__icon wpex-mr-10">
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-open wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">

                   </div>
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-close wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-close" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">

                   </div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Electrochemistry (3 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b08fd">
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Title:
                  </strong>
                  Electrochemistry
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Teacher(s):
                  </strong>
                  Florence VACANDIO
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Credits:
                  </strong>
                  3
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING OUTCOMES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The goal of this lecture is to acquire the basics of electrochemistry and electrochemical methods. Theses basics will help to describe the interest of electrochemistry in the field of nanoengineering through examples of electrochemical nanosynthesis, surface nanostructuration and electrochemical characterizations for analysis purposes, properties (electrochemical and others) determination.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  From this lecture, the student should be able to explain theoretically the behaviour of simple electrochemical interface using the main model in thermodynamics and kinetics. They will also acquire the basic knowledge about the experimental implementation of the main electrochemical techniques that can be used as characterization tool in general or more specifically in nanomaterials. The basics of electrochemical experiment will be applied during a practical session.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING SKILLS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  Students will be able to understand the main principles of electrochemistry and apply them to nanomaterials (synthesis and characterization)
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   PREREQUISITES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  General chemistry.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TOPICS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  1/ Electrochemistry basics: thermodynamics and kinetics applied to electrochemistry
                  <br/>
                  2/ Experimental approach of electrochemistry: steady state and transient methods (voltametry, chronopotentiometry, chronoamperometry, pulse methods…), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.
                  <br/>
                  3/ Application to the synthesis and characterization of nanomaterials (nanoparticles, nanostructured surfaces…)
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   EVALUATION
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  written exam
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   ADOPTED TEXTS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  BARD / ALLEN : Electrochemical Methods: Fundamentals and Applications
                  <br/>
                  Pierre FABRY : Electrochemistry: The Basics, With Examples
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TEACHING METHODS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                  Courses and exercises. Practical session in laboratory.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="vcex-module vcex-toggle" data-animate="true" data-duration="300">
                <div class="vcex-toggle__heading">
                 <a aria-controls="vcex_67ef1648b09b4" aria-expanded="false" class="vcex-toggle__trigger wpex-flex wpex-items-center wpex-transition-colors wpex-duration-200" href="#vcex_67ef1648b09b4">
                  <div aria-hidden="true" class="vcex-toggle__icon wpex-mr-10">
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-open wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-open" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">

                     <path d="M19 13h-6v6h-2v-6H5v-2h6V5h2v6h6v2z">
                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-close wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-close" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">
                     </path>
                     <path d="M19 13H5v-2h14v2z">
                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Solid-state chemistry (Part 1) and nanomaterials (Part 2)(7 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b09b4">
                 <div class="custom animated fadeIn duration3">
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Title:
                   </strong>
                   Solid-state chemistry (Part 1) and nanomaterials (Part 2)
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    Teacher(s):
                   </strong>
                   V. Hornebecq (Part 1) and D. Grosso (Part 2)
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    Credits :  7 ECTS
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    LEARNING OUTCOMES
                   </strong>
                   .
                   <br/>
                   The objectives of the first part of the course is to describe and characterize the crystalline structure of bulk materials. The objective of the second part is to provide a detailed description of the chemical and physical-chemical mechanisms governing the elaboration and implementation of nanostructured inorganic materials (metals, ceramics, hybrids) when combined with processing methods.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   Part 1: The student should understand how to describe a crystal using a unit cell, then how to describe a 3D solid starting from the unit cell. He/she would know all the important classes of crystalline structures. The student should also understand how the crystalline structure and physical properties are linked in a material. He/she would know how to characterize the crystalline structure of solids using X-Ray diffraction.
                   <br/>
                   Part 2:
                   <br/>
                   1) Which method(s), including chemical approaches and material processes, should be selected to elaborate a specific (nano)material, on demand.
                   <br/>
                   2) Understand all physical-chemical parameters that have to be controlled and adjusted during elaboration, handling, and implementation of nanomaterials.
                   <br/>
                   3) Learn advantages, drawbacks and limits associated to theses methods.
                   <br/>
                   4) Understand compatibility between chemical approaches and material processes to combine them and draw a full picture of the nanomaterial elaboration tool-box.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    LEARNING SKILLS
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   Part 1:
                   <br/>
                   Describe a crystal using a unit cell.
                   <br/>
                   Describe a 3D structure starting from a unit cell
                   <br/>
                   Interpret X-Ray diffraction patterns
                   <br/>
                   Understand the relation between crystalline structure and physical properties
                   <br/>
                   Part 2:
                   <br/>
                   Understand the thermodynamic and the kinetic governing the elaboration and implementation of nanostructured materials. How to control the structure at all scales (crystalline structure, nano and micro structures) and the morphologies from 0D to 3D (powder, particles, monolith, porous systems, coatings, fibers, 3D, etc.) of inorganic (metals, ceramics) and hybrid (organics/metal oxides) nanomaterials.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    PREREQUISITES
                   </strong>
                   .
                   <br/>
                   – Understand basic in matter/light interaction
                   <br/>
                   – Understand chemical equilibria (precipitation/dissolution; acid/base; Red/Ox).
                   <br/>
                   – Understand basic thermodynamics and kinetics laws.
                   <br/>
                   – Understand basic physical-chemical phenomenon (capillarity, adsorption, diffusion, etc.).
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    TOPICS
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    Part 1 (16h Lecture, 11h Tutorials and 3h Projects)
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <ol>
                   <li>
                    Introduction on symmetry and crystals
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Symmetry elements
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Lattices and unit cells
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Structure of metallic crystals
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Packing of hard spheres
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Hexagonal close-packing
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Cubic close-packing
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Other type of cubic packing
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Structure of ionic crystals
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Description of interstitial sites
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Cesium and sodium chloride type structures
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Fluorine and Anti-fluorine type structure
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Perovksite type structure
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Structure of covalent crystals
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Blende and wurtzite type structures
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Diamond and graphite
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    X-ray Diffraction
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Production of X-Rays
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Interaction X-Rays/Periodic structure
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Interpretation of powder X-Rays diffraction patterns
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                  </ol>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Part 2
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <ol>
                   <li>
                    <strong>
                     Introduction on nanomaterial properties and applications.
                    </strong>
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      History of nanomaterials.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Properties related to surfaces, curvature and mesoporosity.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Properties related to quantum confinement.
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <strong>
                     Chemistry of inorganic nanomaterials.
                    </strong>
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Nucleation – growth of nano-building blocks and sol-gel chemistry.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Self-assembly of nano-building blocks.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Surface functionalisation of nano-building blocks.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Cristallisation of nanostructured materials.
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <strong>
                     Processing nanomaterials (top-down vs bottom-up).
                    </strong>
                    <ol>
                     <li>
                      Bottom-up methods to powders, coatings, fibres, monoliths.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Top-down methods to supported 0D to 3D nanomaterials.
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Nanocomposites
                     </li>
                    </ol>
                   </li>
                  </ol>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    EVALUATION
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   Type: Part 1: Homeworks, Project and Final examination
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    Description:
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   Part 1: Students will have one homework on crystallography and one homework on X- Ray Diffraction. They will also write a report on the project in Laboratory. Their skills will be also evaluated by a final examination.
                   <br/>
                   Part 2: Final examination
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    TEACHING METHODS
                   </strong>
                   <br/>
                   Part 1: Knowledge of this course will be transmitted through lectures, tutorials and projects in lab, all in an interactive way.
                   <br/>
                   Part 2: The lecture will be provided with illustrations and real everyday-life examples. The learning process will necessitate the students to play an active part in the lecture and participate to discussions.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="vcex-module vcex-toggle" data-animate="true" data-duration="300">
                <div class="vcex-toggle__heading">
                 <a aria-controls="vcex_67ef1648b0b24" aria-expanded="false" class="vcex-toggle__trigger wpex-flex wpex-items-center wpex-transition-colors wpex-duration-200" href="#vcex_67ef1648b0b24">
                  <div aria-hidden="true" class="vcex-toggle__icon wpex-mr-10">
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-open wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-open" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-close wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-close" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">
                     </path>
                     <path d="M19 13H5v-2h14v2z">
                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Organic chemistry of materials (3 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b0b24">
                 <div class="custom animated fadeIn duration3">
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Title:
                   </strong>
                   Organic chemistry of materials
                   <strong>
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   <strong>
                    Teacher(s):
                   </strong>
                   Prof. Elena Zaborova e Prof. Olivier Margeat
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    Credits:
                   </strong>
                   3
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    LEARNING OUTCOMES.
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   The main goal of this course is to provide a general background on structure, reactivity, and synthesis of organic molecules needed for students to get a comprehensive picture of the construction of simple to complex molecular systems. Emphasis is given on the concepts of aromaticity and aromatic chemistry that are relevant to the field of organic nanomaterials with optical, photonic and electronic properties. The beginning of the course will consist of an upgrade of students background on basic concepts on molecular orbitals, electronic effects of substituents, organic reactions, and optical properties – structure relationships. The course also includes an overview of coordination chemistry and its application to modern methods based on transition metal-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions for the generation of functional molecules with extended pi-conjugation.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING.
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   The students should understand the chemical and physical principles that underlie the synthesis, structure and properties of organic molecules The teaching encourages critical thinking in students to help them analyze synthetic approaches described in the scientific literature.
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    <br/>
                    LEARNING SKILLS
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   Course contents are centered on bond formation/cleavage n and transformations of organic molecules to produce functional materials but also encompass a range of general topics such as catalysis, coordination chemistry and physical organic chemistry. The structure of the teaching will allow developing a capacity to connect all these aspects and approaching multidisciplinary subjects in the field of the synthesis and properties of materials.
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    <br/>
                    PREREQUISITES
                   </strong>
                   .
                   <br/>
                   Basic knowledge of Chemistry.
                  </p>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    TOPICS
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <ol>
                   <li>
                    General concepts (upgrade):
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      bonding/antibonding molecular orbitals in organic molecules
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      pi-conjugation and aromaticity
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      resonance/inductive effect of substituents
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      nucleophiles/electrophiles
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      main classes of organic reactions
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Aromatic chemistry:
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      electrophilic aromatic substitution: mechanism, reactions, regiochemistry
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      nucleophilic substitution
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Coordination chemistry:
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      coordination complexes: type of ligands, d-block metals, number of valence electrons
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      structures: octahedral, tetrahedral, and square planar geometries
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      bonding in coordination complexes: crystal-field model and ligand-field theory
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Cross-coupling reactions:
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      catalysis: definition, catalytic cycle
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions: general concepts, palladium coordination   complexes
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      a case study: the Sonogashira reaction
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Optical properties of pi-conjugated organic materials:
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      Electronic absorption, fluorescence
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      Applications in organic electronics
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                  </ol>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    EVALUATION.
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   written examination. The student’s evaluation is based on two written tests and the final evaluation will be obtained averaging the two tests. The aim is to assess the student’s ability to integrate the various topics covered during the course. Therefore the tests include general questions directly related to those topics but also problems based on examples selected from recent publications in order to probe the depth of understanding. The student must demonstrate that she/he has understood the links between the various aspects covered in class and acquired the theoretical knowledge.
                   <br/>
                   <strong>
                    <br/>
                    ADOPTED TEXTS
                   </strong>
                  </p>
                  <ul>
                   <li>
                    Slides provides by Professor
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    Peter C. Volhardt, Neil E. Schore,
                    <em>
                     Organic Chemistry- Structure and Function
                    </em>
                    , 7th edition, W.H. Freeman & Co., New York,
                    <strong>
                     2014
                    </strong>
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                  <p>
                   <strong>
                    TEACHING METHODS
                    <br/>
                   </strong>
                   The course consists of lectures including theory and exercises. A written blank test, based on students’ self-correction, will follow the upgrade courses and will help students assess their level and identify the topics they need to further refine. To this end, the professor will advise students on an individual basis. Two lab work sessions will allow students to get familiar with the manipulation of organic substances and to interact closely with the Professor through discussions.
                  </p>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="vcex-module vcex-toggle" data-animate="true" data-duration="300">
                <div class="vcex-toggle__heading">
                 <a aria-controls="vcex_67ef1648b0c5d" aria-expanded="false" class="vcex-toggle__trigger wpex-flex wpex-items-center wpex-transition-colors wpex-duration-200" href="#vcex_67ef1648b0c5d">
                  <div aria-hidden="true" class="vcex-toggle__icon wpex-mr-10">
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-open wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-open" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">

                     <path d="M19 13h-6v6h-2v-6H5v-2h6V5h2v6h6v2z">
                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                   <div class="vcex-toggle__icon-close wpex-flex wpex-flex-col wpex-items-center">
                    <svg class="vcex-toggle__icon-close" fill="currentColor" height="1.5em" viewbox="0 0 24 24" width="1.5em" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                     <path d="M0 0h24v24H0V0z" fill="none">
                     </path>
                     <path d="M19 13H5v-2h14v2z">
                     </path>
                    </svg>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Computational Modeling of Nanosystems (7 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b0c5d">
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Title:
                  </strong>
                  Computational modeling of nanosystems
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Teachers:
                  </strong>
                  Prof. Mario Barbatti (Masterclasses, Tutorials, Practical Works) and Dr. Vijay Chilkuri (Practical Works)
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Credits:
                  </strong>
                  7
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING OUTCOMES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course aims to provide the basic methodology for computer modeling in chemistry. It surveys the main aspects of the three large areas enabling molecular modeling: quantum mechanics, classical mechanics, and statistical mechanics.
                  <br/>
                  Upon completing this course, students will be able to recognize the main algorithms employed in a theoretical research paper and apply basic methods for the computational modeling of nanosystems.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course focuses on an overall understanding of multiple methodologies. It aims to foster a general scientific culture embracing physics and chemistry, from their fundamentals to applications.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING SKILLS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course stimulates critical thinking, note-taking, problem-solving, information literacy, organization, and communication.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   PREREQUISITES.
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  General Physics, introductory molecular chemistry
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TOPICS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  I – Quantum mechanics
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   Introduction to quantum mechanics and Born-Oppenheimer approximationù
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Quantum chemistry
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Beyond Born-Oppenheimer approximation
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Quantum mechanics in context
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  II – Classical mechanics
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   Newton’s laws
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Molecular mechanics: normal modes
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Molecular mechanics: dynamics
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Hamilton and Lagrange formulations and mixed quantum-classical dynamics
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  III – Statistical mechanics
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   Principles of statistical mechanics
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Monte Carlo algorithms, sampling techniques, and rates
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Fourier transform and spectrum simulations
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Machine learning
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   EVALUATION
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The evaluation is based on three tasks assigned to practical works:
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   Writing a short literature review
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Writing a molecular dynamics program
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Presenting a seminar
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TEACHING METHODS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course comprises three parts, each with four masterclasses followed by tutorials and practical work sections.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   MORE INFORMATION
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  <a href="https://barbatti.org/molecular-modeling" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
                   https://barbatti.org/molecular-modeling
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="vcex-module vcex-toggle" data-animate="true" data-duration="300">
                <div class="vcex-toggle__heading">
                 <a aria-controls="vcex_67ef1648b0d46" aria-expanded="false" class="vcex-toggle__trigger wpex-flex wpex-items-center wpex-transition-colors wpex-duration-200" href="#vcex_67ef1648b0d46">

                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Basic Quantum Chemistry Modelling (3 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b0d46">
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Title:
                  </strong>
                  Basic Quantum Chemistry Modelling
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Teacher(s):
                  </strong>
                  Denis Hagebaum-Reignier and Stéphane Humbel
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Credits:
                  </strong>
                  3 ECTS
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   LEARNING OUTCOMES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The main goal of this course is to learn how to run a quantum chemical calculation and analyze its output. In order to achieve this, students will learn a) the underlying concepts of the different families of quantum chemical methods, b) how to prepare the input of – and run a quantum chemical calculation c) how to extract and analyze the useful information from the output of the calculation.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The students should understand the differences between the major classes of modeling methods: classical (molecular mechanics, MM), quantum (ab initio and semi-empirical wave-function methods, density based methods), mixed classical-quantum methods. They should then be able to critically choose the appropriate theoretical method for the characterization of structural, energetic and spectral properties of the system of their choice. They should understand what information geometry optimization and frequency analysis provide and how to use this information to characterize reaction pathways.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   LEARNING SKILLS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  At the end of the class, the student should able to:
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   Suggest an appropriate quantum chemical method to characterize given molecular properties
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Practically run a quantum mechanical calculation, analyze the results and compare with experimental data
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Use simple models to characterize some properties from quantum chemical calculations
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Read and understand theoretical studies in the literature
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Write a report in scientific format
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   PREREQUISITES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  Basic knowledge in molecular chemistry, quantum mechanics and mathematics.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   TOPICS
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li>
                   Short review of molecular modelling methods, their pros and cons
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   The concept of potential energy surfaces (PES) : stationnary points, gradient vector, Hessian matrix, minimum energy path, intrinsic reaction coordinates.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   What is needed in an input of a quantum chemical calculation? z-matrix, spin multiplicity, basis set, geometry optimization, frequency calculations, specific molecular properties.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Use of quantum chemical software and a graphical interface. The students will gain hands-on experience with performing quantum chemical calculations, and analyzing the results for selected topics that are representative of the use of quantum modelling in the understanding of chemistry:
                   <ol>
                    <li>
                     Energy of the H-atom with different Gaussian basis sets
                    </li>
                    <li>
                     Build a molecule with a graphical interface and run a simple quantum chemical calculation
                    </li>
                    <li>
                     Determination of a reaction pathway
                    </li>
                    <li>
                     Aromaticity in polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons
                    </li>
                    <li>
                     Homodesmic reactions, application to ring strain and steric effects
                    </li>
                   </ol>
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   EVALUATION
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Type:
                   </strong>
                   practical and written examination
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Description:
                   </strong>
                   The practical examination consists of an evaluation of the ability to perform calculations applied to various topics and an evaluation of a written report in a scientific format. The final assessment consists on a written exam on the theoretical concepts and practical tools learned throughout the course.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   ADOPTED TEXTS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  <em>
                   Computational chemistry : introduction to the theory and applications of molecular and quantum mechanics,
                  </em>
                  E.G.Lewars, Springer
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TEACHING METHODS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course is delivered through the following learning activities.
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li>
                   Attendance of lectures where course material is presented through slides, worked examples, and demonstrations.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Attendance of exercises and practicals where students perform and discuss exercises as part of their formative assessment.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Read specific chapters of an accompanying textbook and discuss and/or ask questions about some key concepts in these chapters.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Completion of online quizzes and problems that are designed to give students further practice in the application of course material, as well as feedback on their understanding.
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                </div>
               </div>

                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Thermodynamics of Materials (3 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b0e45">
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Title:
                  </strong>
                  Thermodynamics of Materials
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Teacher:
                  </strong>
                  Philippe Knauth
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Credits:
                  </strong>
                  3 (24 h lectures/exercises, 3 h practice)
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   LEARNING OUTCOMES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course aims to provide students the basic knowledge to understand the equilibrium properties of nanomaterials.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The students should be able to apply equilibrium thermodynamics, including elementary phase diagrams, understand bonds in solids and use defect engineering for the tuning of properties of solids.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   LEARNING SKILLS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  Understanding the relations between thermodynamic properties of materials, bond types and crystal defects. Quantitative understanding of the interaction energies between atoms/ions and molecules at the nanoscale. Theory of crystal defects and defect engineering
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   PREREQUISITES
                  </strong>
                  .
                  <br/>
                  The course starts with a crash course on basics of thermodynamics in order to bring students of various backgrounds to a common level.
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   <br/>
                   TOPICS
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li>
                   Fundamental laws of chemical and materials thermodynamics (principles, state functions, chemical potential, reference states, activity…). Nanosize effects, Gibbs-Thomson equation, fluctuations
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Elements on phase diagrams: Gibbs phase law, lever rule, unary, binary and ternary diagrams. Types of binary phase diagrams: complete miscibility, eutectic, ordered compound. Relation with chemical potential curves (common tangent method). Ideal and regular mixtures
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Basic theory of bonds and modeling of interactions: quantitative understanding of the different bond types (molecular, ionic, covalent and metallic and how the interactions between atoms/ions and molecules can explain materials properties and interesting phenomena at the nanoscale (quantum size effects, wetting, self-assembly…)
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Crystal defects: point defects, dislocations, surfaces and interfaces, defect engineering
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   EVALUATION
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Type:
                   </strong>
                   written exams
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Description:
                   </strong>
                   an intermediate written exam at about half of the course (25% of the final grade) and a final written exam (75 % of the final grade)
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   ADOPTED TEXTS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li>
                   M. Lindsay, Introduction to Nanoscience, Oxford Univ. Press, 2010. Good overview of the field, although some elements are a bit superficial.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Maier, Physical Chemistry of Solids, Wiley, 2004. The “bible” of defect chemistry and defect engineering.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   West, Solid State Chemistry and its Applications, Wiley, 1987. Classical textbook, especially on experimental aspects of thermodynamics.
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TEACHING METHODS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                  Integrated lectures and exercises.
                  <br/>
                  Laboratory practice session in 2 groups (thermogravimetric analysis of an ion-conducting polymer)
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>

                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Nano-Engineering Seminar + Project (2 ECTS)
                  </div>
                 </a>
                </div>
                <div class="vcex-toggle__content wpex-last-mb-0 wpex-my-10 wpex-clr" id="vcex_67ef1648b0f07">
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Title:
                  </strong>
                  Nano-Engineering Seminar + Project
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Teacher(s):
                  </strong>
                  prof. Bogdan Kuchta, prof. Lucyna Firlej
                  <br/>
                  <strong>
                   Credits:
                  </strong>
                  2
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING OUTCOMES
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  The course “Nano-engineering Seminar + Project” is conceived as a forum of exchange for new ideas emerging from the literature and lectures.
                  <br/>
                  The goal is to teach students to work on project, to present its outcome correctly and to be able to defend it. In addition a revision session, where students can express their potential problems and discuss them with other students, under the professor/tutor guidance is planned.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  To integrate knowledge and handle complexity, and formulate judgments in situations characterized by incomplete or limited information,
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   LEARNING SKILLS
                  </strong>
                  <br/>
                  Assure an interdisciplinary training in the field of nano-engineering, which includes a profound understanding of the chemistry and the methods of synthesis and characterization of nano-materials and nano-systems.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   PREREQUISITES
                  </strong>
                  .
                  <br/>
                  Basic physics, inorganic and organic chemistry.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TOPICS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li>
                   Introduction to nanoengineering; nanoscale fabrication: nanolithography and self-assembly;
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Characterization tools; nanomaterials and nanostructures: nanotubes, nanowires, nanoparticles, and nanocomposites;
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Nanoscale and molecular electronics; nanotechnology in magnetic systems; nanotechnology in integrative systems;
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Nanoscale optoelectronics; nanobiotechnology:
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Biomimetic systems, nanomotors, nanofluidics, and nanomedicine.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Synthesis techniques, processes, microstructural control, and unique physical properties of materials in nanodimensions.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Nanowires, quantum dots, thin films, electrical transport, electron emission properties, optical behavior, mechanical behavior, and technical applications of nanomaterials
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Quantum mechanics in nanoelectronics. Wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, free and confined electrons, band theory of solids.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Nanosolids in 0D, 1D, and 2D. Application to nanoelectronic devices
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Chemical principles involved in synthesis, assembly, and performance of nanostructured materials and devices.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Chemical interactions, classical and statistical thermodynamics of small systems, diffusion,
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Carbon-based nanomaterials, supramolecular chemistry, liquid crystals, colloid and polymer chemistry, lipid vesicles, surface modification, surface functionalization, catalysis.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Principles of biochemistry tailored to nanotechnologies.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   The structure and function of biomolecules and their specific roles in molecular interactions and signal pathways.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Nanoscale detection methods.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Understanding nanotechnology, broad implications, miniaturization: scaling laws; nanoscale physics.
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   EVALUATION
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Type:
                   </strong>
                   written examination; project evaluation.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <strong>
                    Description:
                   </strong>
                   Training will be completed by projects and specific seminars. The assessment will take place through oral tests and project reports.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   ADOPTED TEXTS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                  Current literature
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   TEACHING METHODS
                   <br/>
                  </strong>
                  Seminar
                  <br/>
                  Group project
                 </p>
                </div>

                  <div class="vcex-toggle__title">
                   Biomaterials - Biomedical Devices (3 ECTS)
                  </div>
